docs.lead_paragraph: The proposed Republican platform would drop several of the more hard-edged conservative positions adopted four years ago -- like calling for the abolition of the Department of Education -- and transform much of the document's tone to reflect the ''compassionate conservatism'' of Gov. George W. Bush. But it also reflects the continuing power of the party's conservative base, most notably in its word-by-word reaffirmation of the abortion plank, calling for a ban on abortion with no exceptions and the appointment of judges who ''respect traditional family values and the sanctity of innocent human life.''

headline.main: DRAFT  PLATFORM FOR G.O.P. SOFTENS HARD-LINE STANCES

docs.abstract: Proposed Republican platform would drop several of the more hard-edged conservative positions adopted four years ago and transform tone to reflect 'compassionate conservatism' of Gov George W Bush; but document also reflects continuing power of party's conservative base, most notably in its word-by-word reaffirmation of abortion plank, calling for ban on abortion with no exceptions and appointment of judges who respect 'families values' and 'sanctity of innocent human life'; photo of platform committee chairman Gov Tommy G Thompson of Wisconsin (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''With Gore Jabbing at Bush, Texas Takes It on the Chin'' (front page, July 21), about five Texans who are appalled by Al Gore's not-so-pretty depiction of our state and who feel compelled to defend its honor: Since four of those people were contributors to George W. Bush, I feel fairly certain that they aren't the parents of some of the many children without health insurance in Texas. No amount of bluff and bravado can cover up this shameful fact. DAWN LEWIS Austin, Tex., July 25, 2000

headline.main: Reflections: Cheney, Vice Presidents and Texans

docs.lead_paragraph: I wouldn't know a Gibson from a Stratocaster. My favorite guitarists are Django Reinhardt, Eddie Lang and Andres Segovia, and none of them, as far as I know, ever played a single note at the Grand Ole Opry. That could cast a rather long shadow, I suppose, over my qualifications as a guide to Music City, U.S.A., except that there is a lot more than picking and fiddling, a lot more than ballads of love and loss, in Nashville's past, present and future -- especially its future. Which is no bad thing for the city, since country music, which rang up sales of tapes and records of almost $2 billion two years ago, is suffering through a bit of a slump at the moment.
docs.abstract: On the Road article by R W Apple Jr describes Nashville, Music City USA, where convention bureau is trying to play down hillbilly image and emphasize developing cosmopolitanism; reports that what seems most interesting is city's past, and its often neglected role as agent of political and intellectual change from time when rugged old frontiersman Andrew Jackson set off for Washington in 1829; cultural sites also noted; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Both Sides in Mideast Seek To Rekindle Peace Process Amid a flurry of political and diplomatic moves, Israel and the Palestinians indicated that they wanted to put the failed Camp David talks behind them and press on with a renewed peace bid. The sides confirmed negotiators would meet on Sunday at the Gaza Strip border. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: A Florida subsidiary of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York proposed yesterday to gradually eliminate a $4.8 million shortfall in its reserves by laying off 41 workers, cutting other costs and raising insurance premiums, company officials said. Florida regulators placed the subsidiary under special supervision last week. State officials said they were not likely to decide until next week whether to accept or reject the company's plan.

headline.main: Metro Business; Shortfall Proposal By HIP Subsidiary

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign began broadcasting a new 30-second advertisement downstate Tuesday. Unlike previous health care commercials by her campaign, it does not feature or mention her Senate opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio. Instead, in another first, it directly addresses Mrs. Clinton's leading role in the Clinton administration's failed 1993 health care proposal.
docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign begins broadcasting new 30-second advertisement downstate that profiles her health reform proposals; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In denouncing President Clinton's plan to extend Medicare coverage to prescription drugs, and in touting their own counterproposal, Republicans have rolled out the usual rhetoric. They excoriate the administration plan as a bureaucratic, ''one size fits all'' solution. They claim that their plan offers more choice. And for once their claims are absolutely right. The Republican plan does offer more choice. Unfortunately, this is one of those cases in which more choice is actually bad for everyone. In fact, by trying to give people more choices the Republican plan would end up denying them any choice at all.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column holds Republican counterproposal to Pres Clinton's plan to extend Medicare coverage to prescription drugs is unworkable; holds private drug insurance for aged could be offered at reasonable price only if people had to commit to paying necessary premiums before they knew whether they would need costly drugs

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: While people who take genetic tests face tough choices when sharing the results with their families (front page, July 21), there is another serious risk.
docs.abstract: Bonnie Lipton letter comments on July 21 article on tough choices facing people who undergo genetic testing in deciding to share results with families; says there is also risk that information can be used to discriminate against them in absence of comprehensive federal legislation

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''More Extensive Test Needed for Colon Cancer, Studies Say'' (news article, July 20) points out that a colonoscopy, which Medicare and most insurers don't cover unless a patient is at high risk, can be costly. However, most people are unaware that if, at age 50, they have a colonoscopy and are given a clean bill of health, another colonoscopy is not needed for 5 to 10 years. Until insurers recognize that it is more cost effective to prevent colo rectal cancer, rather than to treat the disease, it is important to encourage not only colonoscopy but also all colorectal screening tests. Any screening is better than no screening at all. CAROLYN ALDIGE President, Cancer Research Foundation of America Alexandria, Va., July 23, 2000
docs.abstract: Cancer Research Foundation of America president Carolyn Aldige letter on July 20 article holds colonoscopy is cost effective and should be covered by insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Association of Insurance Commissioners said yesterday that it had begun investigating reports that State Farm, the largest auto insurer, improperly denied claims for treatment of injuries in accidents nationwide. George Nichols III, the president of the association, which represents insurance regulators in all 50 states, said it was not immediately clear how widespread the practice might have been but that investigators intended to study claims for treatment of injuries in all the states.

headline.main: An Insurance Investigation Concentrates on State Farm
